quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The question that I often ask is how have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don't want.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A powerful self-inquiry framework that shifts leaders from blame to agency and ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The purpose of this question is actually to evoke your own agency.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Clarifies the intent behind the “complicit” question as a practical tool for behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A perfect example of that would be, I say I don't want to feel busy all the time, but the truth of the matter is I feel really unnerved and disconcerted if my agenda isn't jam-packed.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how leaders can unconsciously reinforce the very patterns they claim to want to escape.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So if you want to create a high-functioning team, do your work, and it starts with the person who has the most power.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice: team dysfunction often begins with the leader’s unexamined behavior and must be addressed there first.

quotes.topic_title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
quotes.text: The question that I often ask is how have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don't want?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A repeatable self-coaching prompt that helps leaders regain agency when outcomes aren’t matching intentions.

quotes.topic_title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
quotes.text: So I purposely chose the word complicit because complicit does not mean responsible, and that's a really important distinction.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Clarifies the mental model so the question drives empowerment rather than shame or self-blame.

quotes.topic_title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
quotes.text: As I often say, to understand the word complicit, think of the word accomplice. As I will share, you are driving the getaway car, you're not sticking up the bank teller.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A vivid analogy that makes “complicity” concrete and easier to apply in real situations.

quotes.topic_title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
quotes.text: The purpose of this question is actually to evoke your own agency, is to look at the ways in which you may have been diluting yourself.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Defines the practical goal of the exercise: identify self-sabotaging patterns and reclaim choice.

quotes.topic_title: The “complicit” question and personal agency
quotes.text: A perfect example of that would be, I say I don't want to feel busy all the time, but the truth of the matter is I feel really unnerved and disconcerted if my agenda isn't jam-packed.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A specific example showing how unwanted conditions (busyness) can be maintained by an underlying emotional need.

quotes.topic_title: The Reboot equation for better leadership
quotes.text: And so, the equation is practical skills plus radical self-inquiry plus shared experiences, that is the process of actually talking about the craziness that goes on in your head equals greater leadership.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A clear, repeatable leadership framework that combines skill-building with deep reflection and peer learning to drive better outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: The Reboot equation for better leadership
quotes.text: But then, there was this other piece, enhanced resilience. And when I do this on a dry erase board, I will often circle that phrase, and I say that is the purpose of this whole thing, because the truth is, if you follow my story at all, you know that in my late 30s, the depression that had really marked most of my life had gotten so bad that despite my outward success, I was suicidal and lost.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Reframes leadership development around resilience as the primary goal, grounded in a concrete personal example of high achievement alongside severe depression.

quotes.topic_title: The Reboot equation for better leadership
quotes.text: I get you want to be a great CEO, I get you want to be a great executive, but what I really care about is you not killing yourself in the process.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A stark, memorable prioritization that challenges achievement-at-all-costs leadership norms and makes wellbeing a non-negotiable outcome.

quotes.topic_title: The Reboot equation for better leadership
quotes.text: People will come and ask me how, and I will drive them crazy because I will say something like, tell me about your father, or tell me why you chose to be in the job you're in the first place, or tell me about your relationship to money, or tell me about your relationship to self-worth.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Actionable coaching prompts that operationalize “radical self-inquiry” by directing leaders to examine formative drivers behind their behavior.

quotes.topic_title: The big lie of success and happiness
quotes.text: It's not only not the case, it's the big lie that we're socialized with since childhood.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional assumption that external success reliably produces happiness, framing it as a learned cultural myth to interrogate.

quotes.topic_title: The big lie of success and happiness
quotes.text: So what you're telling me is you don't have to be an asshole to be successful.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A vivid real-world takeaway that reframes ambition as compatible with decency, countering the “jerks win” narrative.

quotes.topic_title: The big lie of success and happiness
quotes.text: And of course, the corollary to that is you don't have to feel miserable just because you're trying to create a career.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Directly links career-building to emotional wellbeing, offering a permission slip to pursue success without self-inflicted suffering.

quotes.topic_title: The big lie of success and happiness
quotes.text: To be clear, not everyone ends up in that level of depression, but the hack, if you will, is consciousness.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Provides a practical lever—building consciousness—as the core method for avoiding the success-with-misery trap.

quotes.topic_title: The big lie of success and happiness
quotes.text: What's radical, a radical question to ask is, and what will that do for you? What is it that you believe being "successful" will do for you? How do you define success? Where does that come from?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Offers a concrete self-inquiry framework practitioners can apply to test whether their goals are driven by borrowed definitions of success.

quotes.topic_title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
quotes.text: To be clear, not everyone ends up in that level of depression, but the hack, if you will, is consciousness.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Frames consciousness as the core “hack” for changing patterns that drive unwanted outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
quotes.text: What's radical, a radical question to ask is, and what will that do for you? What is it that you believe being "successful" will do for you? How do you define success? Where does that come from?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Provides a practical self-inquiry checklist for interrogating ambition and redefining success.

quotes.topic_title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
quotes.text: And for me, the stability and what I considered wealth seemed to match to this notion of this endless supply of lemon drops.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A vivid metaphor showing how childhood associations can unconsciously define “wealth” and “safety.”

quotes.topic_title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
quotes.text: And when I got to my 30s and I was outwardly successful and I was a hot shot BC, I had lemon drops, but I didn't feel safe, which was a mindful.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive example that external success can fail to resolve the underlying need it’s meant to fix.

quotes.topic_title: Consciousness, ambition, and the “lemon drops” story
quotes.text: what I encourage people to do is to ask themselves these kinds of questions so that they can raise their level of consciousness so that they can be in the driver's seat of their lives and not some learned behavior that they developed as a child to answer perhaps their parents or grandparents' anxieties.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: use self-questioning to shift from inherited coping strategies to intentional choice.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
quotes.text: And the good news bad news is that's true. That is absolutely true.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: He validates the fear that self-inquiry can force real change, reframing it as an honest (and workable) consequence rather than something to avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
quotes.text: we have this belief system that if I pay no attention to the thing that I'm afraid of, it's somehow going to magically go away.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for avoidance: ignoring discomfort feels protective but is based on a false theory of how emotions and problems resolve.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
quotes.text: More often than not, what we do is we respond to the source of challenge, whether it's a discomfort in our relationship, whether it's a discomfort in the way my life has unfolded. We respond to it by plasting over band-aids and sometimes they're relatively healthy, we become obsessed with working out, or sometimes they're unhealthy. We become obsessed with work or substance abuse or that kind of thing.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: He offers a practical diagnostic: notice “band-aid” behaviors (even socially praised ones) that substitute for addressing the real issue.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
quotes.text: Bruce fucking Springsteen, 25 years in psychoanalysis.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A memorable data point that normalizes long-term inner work even for highly successful people.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of self-inquiry and the cost of avoidance
quotes.text: we all have unsorted baggage, and at some point we're going to pay the price of not sorting that baggage. And the price more often than not is in tears.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A vivid cost-of-avoidance framework: the “price” of postponing self-inquiry compounds and often shows up emotionally later.

quotes.topic_title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
quotes.text: So my famous questions include things like, what am I not saying that I need to say?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A concrete journaling prompt that surfaces avoidance and unlocks direct action in relationships and leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
quotes.text: Corollary questions to that would be, what am I saying that's not being heard? And then, of course, what's being said that I'm not hearing?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A communication diagnostic framework that separates message-sent, message-received, and listening gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
quotes.text: how have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don't want?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A radical accountability question that flips the lens from blaming circumstances to examining one’s own role in outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
quotes.text: You know you're in the radical self-inquiry zone when the questions take your breath away, when the questions, and by the way, you don't have to share the answers to these questions with anybody but yourself.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for identifying high-leverage prompts while lowering the barrier to honesty by keeping answers private.

quotes.topic_title: Practical radical self-inquiry questions to journal
quotes.text: questions that startle us, questions that may cause us to be a little afraid of the answer, that's where the gold is.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb for selecting journaling questions that produce the most insight and behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
quotes.text: And the original iteration of the boot camp, we used to call CEO Boot Camp because it was originally we would get first-time CEOs together and we would do a bait and switch. We would pretend to sell them practical skills, and then I would start asking really tough questions like who would you be without the story of who you are?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for creating shared experience: convene peers around “practical” goals, then shift into deeper identity-level inquiry.

quotes.topic_title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
quotes.text: Because what would happen is imagine sitting in a circle of people who just have your back, who really care about you as a person.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Defines the essential condition for truth-telling communities: relational safety and genuine care, not performance or status.

quotes.topic_title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
quotes.text: And imagine sitting in a group of people who can just hold that space without fixing you, without telling you what you're doing right or wrong?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Actionable facilitation guidance: the practice is “holding space” rather than problem-solving, judging, or advising.

quotes.topic_title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
quotes.text: We, too often than not, especially in what I would say the entrepreneurial community are socialized to bullshit not only ourselves, but everybody else.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis of startup culture that explains why shared experiences are necessary: social norms reward performative optimism over honesty.

quotes.topic_title: Shared experiences: circles, truth-telling, and community
quotes.text: Imagine having the capacity to be in relationship with people where you can just tell the truth. That's what shared experiences are about.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A memorable definition of the outcome: shared experiences build relationships where truth-telling becomes possible.

quotes.topic_title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
quotes.text: What if you could enjoy the puzzle of trying to create something new, trying to create magic, something out of nothing, but it doesn't matter to your sense of self-esteem if you succeed or fail.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A practical reframe for creators/leaders: pursue the work for the craft and curiosity without tying identity to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
quotes.text: So what if you just approached the project as if it was an art project? I think it's going to show up this way. What if it turns out it's wrong? What if it's this? What if it's that? And your sense of self-esteem is not attached to the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Introduces the “art project” methodology as an operating mode that reduces anxiety and enables experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
quotes.text: When we become attached to the outcome, we inadvertently fuel our own suffering.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that outcome-attachment—often seen as “motivation”—can be the root cause of stress and burnout.

quotes.topic_title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
quotes.text: But really the deeper attachment is see, I'm not nothing. See, I'm not a nobody, I'm a somebody, and that's the source of the suffering.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Names the hidden driver behind growth addiction: using achievement to prove worth, which creates a self-reinforcing anxiety loop.

quotes.topic_title: Busyness, growth addiction, and imposter syndrome
quotes.text: Okay. So maybe now at 43, you can take in the fact that you are somebody regardless of what you do.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Direct, actionable identity-level reminder that decouples self-worth from performance—key to sustainable ambition.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've rebuilt it from the ground up with AI.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete methodology shift (re-architecting a product end-to-end) enabled by AI rather than incremental tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV and Excel files with just a simple prompt.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Actionable product/ops insight: move data transformation work from engineers to non-technical teams via prompt-driven automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Debugging these issues is often like finding a needle in a haystack.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why manual data-integration failures are costly and hard to resolve, motivating preventative validation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Practical approach: prevent downstream outages by gating inputs with validation and precise error reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
quotes.text: When we acquire that nice couch, when we buy that nice house that stretches our income to its maximum, if we're doing it to enjoy the couch or the house, then A-OK. But if we're doing it because we're trying to push away the suffering of am I good enough to be loved, to feel safe, and that I belong, that which we do to push away suffering will increase suffering.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for distinguishing healthy enjoyment from attachment-driven consumption that amplifies anxiety.

quotes.topic_title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
quotes.text: You see how the attachment becomes that source of suffering? You see how the thing that we do to make ourselves feel better in fact fuels the tenuous hold that we have on our OK-ness? I'm okay just as I am. I'm okay.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: the coping strategy (attachment) is what destabilizes the very security it seeks to create.

quotes.topic_title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
quotes.text: When my first book came out, Dan Harris, who's a really good friend and client from 10% Happier said to me, "Don't read the Amazon reviews." The truth is, I've read two reviews. I read it in the first hour after it was released, and I've never read a review since because there's no way I can experience those reviews without becoming attached to how people feel.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice for reducing validation-seeking and staying focused on the work itself.

quotes.topic_title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
quotes.text: Whether it turns into a book that people buy or not is secondary, I have to do this work regardless.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A purpose-over-outcome principle that helps practitioners prioritize intrinsic motivation and long-term contribution.

quotes.topic_title: Attachment, comfort, and Buddhist framing of suffering
quotes.text: what do I believe to be true about the world and how do I want to be in that world?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A simple self-inquiry prompt that operationalizes “find your why” into an actionable question for decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
quotes.text: I can't shake the feeling that someone down the line in my lineage is going to ask of me, "And what did you do, grandpa? And what did you do, great grandpa?" I know what I want that answer to be, which is I tried.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A practical “future descendant audit” framing for clarifying what you want to stand for and how you’ll be judged over time.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
quotes.text: Lenny, God gave me the ability to put two sentences together in a way that people listen. I feel a moral responsibility to use that God-given gift to help create the world, that I would like to see, a world of kindness and empathy, a world where poverty is diminished, a world where people feel safe however the fuck they identify.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Turns “legacy” into an actionable responsibility: identify your specific leverage (your gift) and deploy it toward concrete outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
quotes.text: And I look at the tree and I say to myself, "Here lies a good man."
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A memorable, embodied metaphor for evaluating a life by the net effect of one’s presence rather than perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
quotes.text: But that for the majority of its 75, 80 years, it lived into its purpose of providing shelter and shade for those that may have come from beneath it.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A simple purpose test practitioners can apply: did your work/life reliably create “shelter and shade” for others over time?

quotes.topic_title: Legacy, meaning, and being a “good ancestor”
quotes.text: My suffering is eased when I can lean into that, which then makes me able to be present for the other person, whether it's a coaching client, whether it's a podcast conversation, whether it's just going for a walk with one of my children.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive link between meaning-making and performance: purpose reduces suffering and increases presence in day-to-day interactions.

quotes.topic_title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
quotes.text: A year ago, I thought we were going through a similar kind of transition. We're clearly not. This is different.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Reframes AI as a fundamentally different shift than prior tech waves, prompting leaders to update their mental models rather than rely on past playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
quotes.text: What I am finding is in my own life, it's like I have put on a pair of glasses that are really, really sharp and helpful, and it is disturbing and unsettling because I think it does challenge this question of what is our role as human beings?
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A vivid metaphor for AI as a cognitive amplifier that simultaneously improves capability and forces identity/role reconsideration.

quotes.topic_title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
quotes.text: What I am hopeful about is that that which does not matter in the experience of being human gets burned away and is taken care of, call it by AI, but that that which matters, which is presence and connection, human-to-human contact, strategic thinking, formulation, you want to talk about it in terms of engineering, the conceptualization, that that gets elevated and our skills get better at doing that.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: An actionable prioritization framework: let AI absorb low-value work while doubling down on uniquely human strengths (presence, connection, strategy, conceptualization).

quotes.topic_title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
quotes.text: Look, one of my colleagues in the coaching company, he has uploaded, he kept all of his journal entries, I think over 10 years journal entries from Evernote, and he uploaded that.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: A concrete example practitioners can copy: use an LLM on long-term personal data (journals) to surface patterns and blind spots.

quotes.topic_title: AI anxiety and what remains uniquely human
quotes.text: I am finding, I'm using ChatGPT really as a writing and thinking partner in a way that I did not have before, and I'm still using my live real human writing buddies, which are really important to me.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Colonna
quotes.context: Practical hybrid approach: treat LLMs as a thinking partner without replacing human relationships and feedback loops.
